text:
Introduction

Indeed, all praise is due to Allah; we praise Him, seek His help, and ask for His forgiveness. We seek refuge in Allah from the evils of our souls and from the bad consequences of our deeds. Whomever Allah guides, there is no misguider for him, and whomever He leads astray, there is no guide for him. And I testify that there is no deity worthy of worship but Allah - alone, having no partner -. And I testify that Muhammad is His slave and Messenger.

To proceed:
Before you - O noble reader - is my book "The Advice..."; it consists of critical scientific Hadith researches; built upon correct rules, and established upon explicit principles; proceeding upon what the Imams of Islam - the prominent preservers of the Sunnah - left behind for those after them of their followers; those who tread - truthfully - upon their methodology, and walk - with sincerity - their path and way.

The origin of these researches are responses to a (novice) among the novice youth (1); who undertook what
foot_note: 1. (1) He is the one called (Hassan Abdul-Mannan)! And it has been confirmed to me that he has started publishing his books - lately - after his reality was uncovered and his affair exposed - under the name (Abu Suhaib Al-Karmi)!! Indulging in deception and camouflage! And drowning in misleading and fraud!! Indeed, he - afterwards - published books containing his introductions and bearing his comments: without any name or Kunya!! And so that the reader may stand upon images of his (sabotage) of the books of the people of knowledge - other than what is in this book of ours -: let him look at his work in "Sahih Al-Bukhari" which he brought out in a single volume! To see the evil of his work, the corruption of his action, and what occurred in it of omission, misspelling, distortion, and confusion... Indeed, I suspect - after my experience with him and knowing him - that (some) of that is intentional from him, for he =

Hadiths! And blackened pages with comments! And spoke - with extreme boldness - in what he has no capability in, regarding the intricacies of the science of terminology (Mustalah), and the principles of disparagement and validation (Jarh wa Ta'dil)!!! So there came from him a large, broad corruption, and there issued from him much sick speech; the reality of its extent is known only by his Lord and Master - Exalted be He in His Highness -.
And I had refuted him - before - in multiple places in my books - especially "Silsilah Al-Ahadith Al-Sahihah" - for occasions that arose; in which I exposed his ignorance, and clarified his reality; where it appeared to me - with all clarity - that he is a (destroyer) of the Sunnah, and an aggressor against the truth. He assaults authentic Hadiths with conjecture, ignorance, corruption, and sabotage; with what agrees with his desire, and meets what he sees - under the claim of verification and referencing! - ...
And I saw of his - some time ago - a verification - rather a sabotage - of the book "Ighathat Al-Lahfan min Masa'id Al-Shaitan" (Rescue of the Sorrowful from the Traps of Satan) by Imam Ibn Qayyim al-Jawziyya, the student of Sheikh al-Islam Ibn Taymiyyah

Just as he - sometimes - drops some words from a certain text, and adds other words in another text; which leads to causing corruption in the meaning of the Hadiths, and confusion in their indication!! So his corruption is diverse: in narration and in understanding!! And with all of this; he claims verification (and corrects the verifiers!); knowing that such mistakes - nay sins! - did not occur in any of the prints of "Al-Bukhari" or others!! So it is said to him: This is not your nest, so go away... And to stand upon examples of what I mentioned, one can refer to what our companion brother Ali Al-Halabi wrote - regarding that - in the magazine (Al-Asalah - Issue: 20/ pp. 47-51). And {Indeed, your Lord is in observation}...

And I know that some of our brothers, the callers to the Sunnah - or those keen on it - (might) say to themselves: Is there not in this refutation publicity for this ignorant person, and introduction of this (destroyer)?!!
So I say: So what?! Is it not obligatory to expose the ignorance of the ignorant to warn against him?! Is this not - itself - the path of the scholars of Islam - since ancient times - to refute every deviant attacker, and criticize every overreaching destroyer?! Then, is not silence about the likes of him a path by which the common people and the masses, and the rabble are deceived?! So let it be - then - what may be; for advice is the foundation of the religion, and exposing the falsifier is preservation of the clear truth; {And Allah will surely support those who support Him...}; even after a while... And the condition of the predecessor of this (destroyer) - that (Al-Saqqaf) - and what he ended up to - and praise be to Allah - is not far from those who know the truth and its callers...
Finally; if this (destroyer) had any fairness: there would have been from him - even a little - application and compliance with what some of the senior people of knowledge said - as advice and direction -: "It is not befitting for a man to see himself worthy of something; until he asks who is more knowledgeable than him (1)"! But; far, far away; for vanity is a killer, and the love of fame breaks the back...
Yet with all this; I ask Allah - Glory be to Him - for guidance to the truth for him, and return to

Entrance

The observer of the scribblings of this ignorant (destroyer) notices comprehensive general issues; by which his (methodology) is revealed to him - which is in its reality and outcome: no methodology; except ignorance! And destruction and overreaching without knowledge!!

* The first of these general issues: That his referencings - rather his sabotages - are mostly abbreviated and do not quench thirst; that is because they are of three types:
First: What he attributes to the Two Sheikhs (Bukhari and Muslim) or one of them, it does not imply that it is authentic according to him, for he is known not to give weight to them nor to others from the dozens of Hafizs (Hadith Preservers); if they oppose his opinion! How many authentic Hadiths have they extracted and authenticated, which he weakened from his own side with extreme ignorance in this referencing, and in his commentary on his edition of the book "Riyad al-Salihin"! - especially in what he appended to it - there are several examples, and I have clarified some of that at the end of the second volume of "Al-Sahihah", the new edition, see for example: Rectification (6).
So if he generalizes the attribution to them or to one of them, it does not necessarily mean that it is authentic according to him, so one should not be deceived by it. I have seen him in his commentary on "Collection of Treatises of Sheikh Muhammad Nasib Al-Rifa'i - may Allah have mercy on him" (p. 125) attributing a Hadith to Muslim restricted by his saying: "with a strong chain"! This obliges him to clarify to the readers what is the principle according to him regarding what the Two Sheikhs or one of them narrated!
Second: What he attributes to others besides them from the authors of "Al-Sunan" and "Al-Masanid" and others, he

remains silent about them, and rarely declares the authenticity of any of them or grades them Hasan. Sometimes he deliberately obscures their authenticity; either by concealing the statement of those who authenticated them from the Imams or Hafizs - and they might be among those who extracted the Hadith -, or by his saying: "Its men are trustworthy", and this is not a textual declaration of authenticity - as is known among scholars -.
Third: What he weakens of them; here his style differs from disruptive brevity to harmful expansiveness. You find him attacking and roaming (!), expanding on discussing the paths of the Hadith, and impugning the narrators, and prolonging the breath in that very much - in several pages, and in small font! - pretending that he is a verifier researcher, while in most cases he is a falsifier and an aggressor against knowledge, weakening the Hadith of the Messenger of Allah, may Allah's peace and blessings be upon him, without proof, and opposing the masses of Hafizs and early Imams, and verifying scholars. Until it becomes predominantly thought that he did not undertake referencing in this form - abbreviated on one side, and expanded on the other! - except to demolish the Sunnah, and weaken its Hadiths, especially what was among them regarding encouragement to hold fast to the Sunnah, and what the righteous predecessors, may Allah be pleased with them, were upon.
He is in this - all of it - either following his desire, or imitating his likes from the people of desires who do not follow the principles of the scholars and their Hadith and Fiqh rules, as I used to think of him at my first perusal of some of his referencings. Then during my discussion with him in my home - in Ramadan of the year (1412) - regarding his weakening of the Hadith of Al-Irbad bin Sariyah - the raised (Marfu') one -: "Stick to my Sunnah and the Sunnah of the Caliphs...", despite the multitude of its paths, and the authentication of a large crowd of Hafizs and scholars - for it -.
Then I became certain of that after I stood upon other numerous weakenings - of his -

of authentic Hadiths using twisted unscientific methods, and weak personal opinions, which any generally educated person, ignorant of this science, arrogant, would not be incapable of!!

* As for the second of his issues; he - despite the rarity of what he authenticates or grades Hasan - generalizes the speech and does not detail nor clarify the reason for that; rather he says: "Sahih" (Authentic), or: "Hasan" (Good), then walks away! And the readers must submit to him in submission, because he is (Hazam)! It is not hidden that clarifying the truth in that is either by quoting from scholars - if he is not one of them, as is his reality -, or by his own explanation - if he was qualified for that - as this one deluded by himself claims for himself -.
The most confirmed thing that should be explained is if he grades it Hasan and does not authenticate it (Sahih); because grading Hasan implies that there is weakness in some of its narrators, so it should be revealed, and the cause of weakness, so that the reader is insightful about his matter.
And more obligatory than all that is explaining if it was authentic due to others (Sahih li-Ghayrihi), or Hasan due to others (Hasan li-Ghayrihi). This requires the researcher - if he is truly a scholar and sincerely devoted - to track the paths and witnessing narrations (Shawahid) that raise the Hadith to the degree of authenticity if they are many, or Hasan if they are few. All of this is what the man does not turn to! And I find no reason for that except one of two matters:
First: That he does not truly adopt what the scholars are upon in the science of terminology regarding the division of established Hadith into two parts: Sahih and Hasan, i.e., intrinsic (li-Dhatihi), then their division into Sahih and Hasan - due to others (li-Ghayrihi) -.
The other: That he adopts that, but he cannot perform it, or does not want to perform it, because he specialized in weakening authentic Hadiths with the flimsiest arguments, and does not care

book_title: The Advice Warning Against the Sabotage of (Ibn Abdul-Mannan) to the Weighty Books of the Imams and His Weakening of Hundreds of Authentic Hadiths

to strengthen weak Hadiths with follow-ups and witnesses, the fruits of which are the Hadith Sahih due to others and Hasan due to others according to scholars - as preceded -. This latter one is what some of his referencings indicate, i.e., that he does not want to track Hadiths Sahih or Hasan due to others - as I mentioned -.
Added to that; achieving that requires research and exhausting effort in many Hadiths. How so, when he is stingy and reluctant sometimes to declare the authenticity of the chain of some Hadiths that do not agree with his desire, and suffices therein by saying: "The men of its chain are trustworthy"! While his right is to say: "Its chain is authentic, its men are trustworthy."
As for the first division: Sahih and Hasan, he uses it in some Hadiths, rarely - as preceded -, and without explanation. However, he casts doubt on some of them sometimes by coupling that with his saying: "If Allah Almighty wills"! - as you will see -; so you do not know if that is from him as verification or commentary?! And this latter one is more apparent!!
The reason for his lack of clarification for what we mentioned - of authentication and grading Hasan - in what became clear to me from tracking his referencings -; is so he does not reveal his methodology in that, and that if he did, he would be (like one digging his own grave with his hoof) as it is said...
Let us bring that closer to the readers with an example: What he authenticated of Hadiths or graded Hasan, if he explained the reason, it would oblige him to authenticate or grade Hasan Hadiths he himself weakened! For it has preceded that the Hasan Hadith only descended from the rank of authenticity because there is weakness in some of its narrators. So if he clarified the narrator whom he accuses of weakness, it would be binding upon him to grade his other Hadiths as Hasan. So for that reason, he conceals and does not explain, especially since in many of the Hadiths he weakens, he does not increase in explaining the cause of weakness beyond saying: "It contains so-and-so and in him is weakness" - and he might not

name him! -, so his saying: "in him is weakness" - and this is if he means what he says - equals the saying of the sayer: "And its chain is Hasan; because so-and-so has weakness in him." So if he named the narrator whose Hadith he graded Hasan, he would be exposed, and it would become clear that he does not adhere to scientific Hadith rules, and this is a certainty to me; {And none can inform you like one who is aware}!
Likewise, it is said if he explained that the Hadith is authentic due to others, or Hasan due to others, he would be obliged to authenticate or grade Hasan many of the Hadiths he weakened after listing their numerous paths. The closest example of that is the Hadith of Al-Irbad. Yet; he did not refrain from weakening it - as you will see in my refutation of him number (2) -. You find under it another example; which is his weakening of the Hadith "Follow those after me...", even though he extracted it from four paths, and a group strengthened it, but he paid no attention to all that! A matter which makes the researcher feel that he does not consider the rule of strengthening Hadith by multiple paths which is considered by all scholars - among them Sheikh Al-Islam Ibn Taymiyyah may Allah have mercy on him; and he has a great research in supporting and explaining it, which I quoted in my treatise on "Refutation of Ibn Hazm regarding his permitting musical instruments and on his imitators" (1) - and among them is this (Destroyer), as you will see under Hadith (79) -. Therefore, you hardly find a Hadith he strengthens relying on this rule. Like him in this are some ignorant upstarts, and perhaps among them is the author of the treatise: "Bazl al-Juhd fi Tahqiq Hadithay al-Suq wal-Zuhd" (Exerting Effort in Verifying the Hadiths of the Market and Asceticism); for he weakened the Hadith of the Market - having extracted it from seven paths, and most of them do not contain an accused person -, and I have refuted him in some of them which Al-Hafiz graded the chain Hasan in "Al-Sahihah" (3139).

* As for the third of the calamities of this (Destroyer); when he tracks the paths of the Hadith he planned to weaken, and references them - attributing to sources with their volume and page numbers -:

he pretends that this is from his labor and extraction from them! But it is - in reality - from those who preceded him of extractors from the predecessors or later ones. The other: Two trustworthy narrators narrate it from him—at length—similar to the narration of Ibn Salamah. If this is known, what is the preponderant view from this difference? It is clear that what two trustworthy narrators agree upon is preponderant over what a single trustworthy narrator narrates, especially if his narration is shorter in text than theirs. So the narration of Abd al-Rahman bin Mahdi is outweighed from this perspective, but we see that two other trustworthy narrators followed him: Ma'mar and Sulayman bin Al-Mughirah, so by this consideration, it is preponderant, and the narration of the two trustworthy narrators is outweighed; this is if we proceeded—Allah forbid!—upon what (Al-Haddam) proceeded upon regarding prepoderance by numbers! Before starting to explain this summarized speech, I must draw the readers' attention to this (Haddam's) ignorance of the art of extraction (Takhrij), and the difference between the wording of a Hadith and another Hadith—regarding their difference in indication. We saw that Ibn Al-Qayyim mentioned his prohibition, peace and blessings be upon him, of wearing the skins of leopards and predators; yet (Al-Haddam) did not mention in his critique and extraction of the two Hadiths this wording, but rather mentioned it with the wording: "He forbade the skins of predators"! And this is the wording of Usamah's Hadith. And from the completeness of his opposition and quarrelsomeness towards me, and his bad extraction: he started his extraction before extracting the Hadith of Al-Miqdam, whose wording agrees with what Ibn Al-Qayyim mentioned; so he did not mention it, obscuring its meaning towards what the meaning of the wording he mentioned might indicate; which does not agree with the explicit meaning of Al-Miqdam's Hadith. text: So I say: Thus—also—he casts doubt on the person of (Baqiyyah), then turns his back, neither explaining what his status is, nor what his position regarding him is, so he wavers in his doubt! The truth is that there is much speech regarding (Baqiyyah) that confuses the ignorant who have no knowledge of this art, and the science of Jarh (criticism) and Ta'dil (praise). So whoever claims knowledge and understanding; he must explain his point of view regarding what was said about him, based on {Bring your proof}, not merely a claim that no one is incapable of. Here is Imam Al-Dhahabi the Critic—with his mention of the disagreement referred to in his book "Al-Mughni"—he exaggerated in praising him, indicating that those Munkar narrations are forgivable relative to the abundance of his Hadith, so he said of him: "One of the Imam Huffaz, he narrates from whoever walked and crawled (everyone), and he has strange narrations that are denounced—also—from trustworthy narrators; due to the abundance of his Hadith..." then he mentioned the sayings about him, and concluded them with the saying of Al-Nasa'i: "If he says: (Haddathana - He told us), and (Akhbarana - He informed us), then he is trustworthy." text: And my answer to this negation, and my rebuttal to (Al-Haddam) who claimed Sa'id's isolation in connecting it—imitating Al-Tirmidhi; whom he does not trust unless he agrees with his whim, and who prevents him from recounting his opposition to him!—is from two aspects: First: The known rule among rational people let alone scholars: "Lack of knowledge of a thing does not necessitate knowledge of its non-existence," for a thing might exist and some know it while others do not, and this is a self-evident matter needing no proof. I believe no one disputes it except a doubting sophist, or a (Haddam) hostile to correctness! Since the matter is so, its implication is that if a trustworthy narrator affirms something, and does not affirm what negates it, he is a proof. The matter here is likewise, because Yazid Al-Rishk's Mursal narration has been proven to be outweighed—due to the disturbance of narrators regarding him in connection and sending—; so it is not suitable as evidence to negate the affirming narration. Rather, it is closer that the narration of connection is preponderant; due to its agreement with Sa'id's affirming narration, and thus it becomes a witness for it, strengthening it. So reflect on this; for it is from the subtleties of this science which we benefited from their extractions and scientific investigations, may Allah reward them with good. As for (Al-Haddam's) saying: "And Sa'id was contradicted..."—then he mentioned the narration of Hisham Al-Dastuwa'i, from Qatadah, from Abu Al-Malih; that he disliked predator skins: This is from his ignorance and aggression, as there is no contradiction between a narrator's saying and the requirement of his Hadith. Rather, this is obligatory on every Muslim to act upon the Prophet's Hadith and issue Fatwas by it, and the narrator of it is foremost in that—as is not hidden. Then this (Al-Haddam) always mentions what is for him—as he thinks—and conceals all that is against him—as he believes. Among what he concealed here is Shu'bah's narration from Qatadah... with it, like Sa'id's narration; Al-Tabarani extracted it (509) following Sa'id's narration, saying: Abdullah bin Ahmad told us: Abu Kurayb told us: Ibn Al-Mubarak told us, from Shu'bah... with it. I say: (The Destroyer) was not pleased - as is his habit - with Al-Tirmidhi's authentication -, nor did he consider Ibn al-Qayyim's approval of it. It is most likely to me that he points by mentioning the first part of the chain to his attacking (Amr bin Asim Al-Thaqafi), because his narrator (Ya'la bin Ata') is trustworthy by agreement, and Muslim used him as proof. As for his Sheikh (Amr bin Asim), no one validated him except Imam Ahmad, Ibn Hibban, and Al-Hafiz, and no one narrated from him except two trustworthy narrators - (Ya'la) is one of them -. So I think he rejects this validation relying on delusions and imaginations having no control or rules; except (as he pleases!); and he might invent a defect in it, saying for example: His hearing from Abu Hurayrah is not known - and similar to what happened to him in some authentic Hadiths -, see - for example - his "Da'ifah" (p. 535 - 536).

Fourth: Not only this, but he fabricates against him regarding his description of the Prophet peace and blessings be upon him that he was the most eloquent speaker of the letter Dad, saying: (p. 58): "He took it from a Hadith, I am the most eloquent who spoke with Dad, and it has no basis"! This is a lie against the Sheikh, may Allah have mercy on him, for the mentioned attribute is known in him peace and blessings be upon him by consensus; its affirmer does not need such a Hadith, but it is arrogance, and pretending to have what he was not given. =

Al-Tirmidhi (1626) -: "It contains Mu'awiyah bin Salih and he is not solid (Matin)"! Thus in his "Da'ifah" which is in the tail of his "Riyad" (p. 544).

Al-Darimi (2/322) and Ahmad (4/182) narrated it from the path of Safwan bin Amr: Yahya bin Jabir the Judge narrated to me, from Al-Nawwas bin Sam'an... with it.

As for its witnesses; they are many. Hafiz Ibn Rajab referenced many good ones in his commentary on "Al-Arba'in Al-Nawawiyyah" (p. 181-182) under this Hadith, let whoever wishes check them. 41 - "And Anas may Allah be pleased with him said: The Messenger of Allah peace and blessings be upon him said: 'Do not be hard on yourselves lest Allah be hard on you, for a people were hard on themselves, so Allah was hard on them, so those are their remnants in hermitages and monasteries, {And monasticism, they invented it; We did not prescribe it for them}'":
I say: Ibn al-Qayyim asserted attributing it to the Prophet peace and blessings be upon him, and it is the correct view. Know - O noble reader! - that the Hadith was narrated by Ibn Abi Al-Amya', from Sahl bin Abi Umamah, from Anas - raised -... with it, and it contains a story. This Ibn Abi Al-Amya' is of unknown condition, therefore I referenced his Hadith in its entirety in "Al-Da'ifah" (3468).
As for this portion which Ibn al-Qayyim mentioned, it is authentic, because this Sa'id was followed up on it, even if he was opposed in its chain: Abu Shurayh Abdur-Rahman bin Shurayh Al-Iskandarani - the Trustworthy - said: From Sahl bin Abi Umamah bin Sahl bin Hunayf, from his father, from his grandfather - raised -... with it similarly, until his saying: "and monasteries", without what follows it.
I say: So he made it from the Musnad of (Sahl bin Hunayf), and this is an authentic chain; narrated by Al-Bukhari in "Al-Tarikh", and Al-Tabarani in "Al-Mu'jam Al-Kabir", and "Al-Awsat", and Al-Bayhaqi and others. I referenced it in "Al-Sahihah" (3124), and spoke on its chain, and supported it in there with two Mursal witnesses, the chain of one of them is authentic, such that one standing on that does not doubt that the Hadith is authentic without doubt.

So what do readers say about one who was ignorant of - or ignored - these facts, paths, and sources, and limited himself to the path of Ibn Abi Al-Amya' and his single source?! O Allah guide you!

42 - "He peace and blessings be upon him said: 'The pen is lifted from three: The insane until he recovers, the sleeper until he wakes up, and the boy until he reaches puberty'":
(The Destroyer) weakened it (1/191) after attributing it to a group of authors of "Al-Sunan" - and others; like Ibn Al-Jarud, Ibn Hibban, and Al-Hakim among authors of "Al-Sihah" - from the Hadith of Aisha may Allah be pleased with her; and said with extreme ignorance: "And in Hammad bin Abi Sulayman there is weakness, and it has witnesses from Ali, Ibn Abbas, Abu Hurayrah and others, and in all their chains there is speech, and it is likely to be Mawquf (1)"!!
Thus said (the Pseudo-Mujtahid) the pretender to knowledge! Indifferent to his opposition to all scholars among Muhaddithin, Exegetes, Usulis, and Jurists, who used it as proof in establishing rules and branches. Among them is Abu Al-Wafa' Ibn Aqil who used it as proof - as Ibn al-Qayyim mentioned - against the whisperer (Muswaswis) who immersed himself in water many times, then asked: Is my Ghusl valid or not? So Ibn Aqil answered him saying: "Prayer has dropped from you"!... And he argued against him with the Hadith saying: "Whoever immerses himself in water many times and doubts: did water touch him or not? He is insane!".
(The Destroyer) blinded himself to this, just as he blinded himself to the authentication of the authors of "Al-Sihah" mentioned - and others; like Ibn Khuzaymah, Abdul-Haqq Al-Ishbili, Ibn Daqiq Al-Eid, Al-Dhahabi, Al-Asqalani - and others -, just as he opposed the majority who validated the Faqih Imam Hammad bin Abi Sulayman; for slight speech in him from some of them. While the Critic Hafiz Al-Dhahabi said: "Trustworthy, Imam, Mujtahid, generous, munificent." And Muslim used him as proof.

And (the Destroyer's) saying: "And in all their chains there is speech": is an exposed lie; for the Hadith of Ali - which he evaded referencing - has alone four paths, one of which is authentic, as you see it verified in "Al-Irwa" (2/4-7), and Al-Hakim and Al-Dhahabi authenticated it, as did Ibn Khuzaymah and Abdul-Haqq, and Al-Tirmidhi graded one of its other chains Hasan.
And his saying: "And it is likely to be Mawquf"! I say: Upon whom; O...?! Upon Aisha?! Or Ali?! Or Ibn Abbas?! Or Abu Hurayrah?! And others whom you folded their mention - like Thawban, and Shaddad -?! Whoever says regarding such a Hadith narrated from these Companions your saying this; the best of his conditions is to be like the one regarding whom Ibn Aqil said what preceded!
Finally, this Hadith is among the many examples indicating that (the Destroyer) does not adopt what scholars are upon regarding strengthening Hadith by multitude of paths free from severe weakness - as preceded in explanation in the Introduction number (2) -.

43 - "And Abu Dawood narrated in his 'Sunan' from the Hadith of Abdullah bin Mughaffal, he said: I heard the Messenger of Allah peace and blessings be upon him say: 'There will be in this Ummah people who transgress in purification and supplication'":
I say: (The Destroyer) referenced it from the path of Hammad bin Salamah, from Sa'id Al-Jurayri, from Abu Na'amah Qais bin Abayah, from Abdullah bin Mughaffal, and faulted it with disconnection between Qais and Abdullah; clinging to the condition of Meeting - which we proved in the Introduction is a condition of perfection not a condition of validity, so we will not prolong speech refuting it -, and faulted it saying: "And it is not far that Hammad bin Salamah heard it from Al-Jurayri during his confusion"! This confirms his fighting against the Sunnah, because it is mere postulation based on desire to demolish it, and if someone opposed him and turned his saying against him; he could not refute it!

text:
However, his saying is invalid; because it contradicts the saying of Hafiz Al-Ijli in "Tarikh Al-Thiqat" (181/531) that Hammad bin Salamah heard from him before confusion, which is Abu Dawood's saying also; and Muslim's action by narrating it from him in his "Sahih".
Then (the Destroyer) faulted it with another defect; which is the opposition of Ziyad bin Mikhraq who narrated it from Qais, from a freed slave of Sa'd bin Abi Waqqas, from a son of Sa'd... - raised -, so he said: "And this according to me (!) is more correct, despite the weakness of its chain"! This is like its predecessor; its pillar is desire and whim! Moreover, the weakness he pointed to; is not the anonymity of the freed slave - only - as felt by his concealment of the real defect which Imam Ahmad explicitly stated -; for he was asked about this Hadith of Ziyad? He said: "He did not establish its chain". Indicating that he was confused in it, and we clarified that in "Sahih Abi Dawood" (1330).

97 - "And he peace and blessings be upon him said: 'The one repenting from sin is like one who has no sin'":
Ibn al-Qayyim asserted its attribution to the Prophet peace and blessings be upon him, and it is the correct view scholars are upon, and Hafiz Al-Asqalani, Al-Sakhawi - and others - graded it Hasan due to its witnesses -, Hafiz Al-Mundhiri indicated that in "Al-Targhib" (4/75/17), and I proceeded on that in "Al-Da'ifah" - under Hadith (615) -, and included it in "Sahih Al-Jami' Al-Saghir" (3005).
As for (the Destroyer): He strayed - as is his habit - from the path, so he extracted it (1/469) from the narration of Ibn Majah only from Ibn Mas'ud; and said: "And in it is disconnection, and nothing is authentic in the chapter"!! This is a trace of the traces of his deviation from scholars' rules; which include strengthening Hadith by paths, for he does not raise a head to them, may Allah guide him!

98 - "...Amr bin Shu'ayb, from his father, from his grandfather, that the Prophet peace and blessings be upon him said: 'The two sellers have the option until they separate, unless it is a deal of option, and it is not lawful for him to separate from him fearing he might cancel'; Ahmad and the people of 'Al-Sunan' narrated it, and Al-Tirmidhi graded it Hasan":
(The Destroyer) faulted it (1/481) saying - as is his habit -: "And in this chain is speech". You have known the answer to it recently, and Ibn Al-Jarud, Ibn Daqiq Al-Eid in "Al-Ilmam" (336/881), and Al-Hafiz in "Al-Fath" (4/331) authenticated it by his silence on it, and attributed it in "Bulugh Al-Maram" to Ibn Khuzaymah in his "Sahih", and it is referenced in "Al-Irwa" (1311).

99 - "Muhammad bin Amr narrated, from Abu Salamah, from Abu Hurayrah, that the Messenger of Allah peace and blessings be upon him said: 'Do not commit what the Jews committed, so you make lawful the prohibitions of Allah with the slightest

tricks', Abu Abdullah bin Batta narrated it... and this is a good (Jayyid) chain like which Al-Tirmidhi authenticates":
(The Destroyer) said (1/481): "Ibn Kathir mentioned it in his 'Tafsir' in two places (1/114-115) and (2/286), and said: 'This is a good chain, for this Ahmad bin Muhammad bin Salm; Al-Khatib mentioned him in his "Tarikh" and validated him, and the rest of its men are famous trustworthy, and Al-Tirmidhi authenticates with such a chain often'; I say: I did not find him in 'Tarikh Baghdad'; so the Hadith remains weak".
I say: I had mentioned this negation in referencing the Hadith in "Al-Irwa" (5/375), so (the Destroyer) imitated me in it - as you see -, then I retracted it when I found his biography in "Al-Tarikh" (4/362) - by the guidance of a brother - may Allah reward him well -; and behold he is in it thus: "Ahmad bin Muhammad bin Ahmad bin Salm"; so (Salm) is the grandfather of (Ahmad's) father, and Al-Khatib said: "He was trustworthy". But the Hadith has another defect; I mentioned it in "Ghayat Al-Maram" (23-24); so let whoever wishes review it (1).

100 - "Ibn Majah narrated from Ubadah bin Al-Samit - raising it -: 'People from my Ummah will drink wine, calling it by other than its name', and Imam Ahmad narrated it; and its wording: 'A group of my Ummah will surely make wine lawful, calling it by other than its name':
(The Destroyer) said (1/485): "Ibn Majah extracted it (3385), and Ahmad (5/318), and its chain is weak"! Thus he said - may his mouth be smashed -, and did not mention a defect for it, and there is no weakened person in it nor a defect

mentioned, rather its chain is good (Jayyid), yet he blinded himself to Ahmad's narration - the other one - (4/237) from the path of Shu'bah, from Abu Bakr bin Hafs, he said: I heard Ibn Muhayriz, narrating from a man of the Companions of the Prophet peace and blessings be upon him, he said: The Messenger of Allah peace and blessings be upon him said: "Indeed people of my Ummah will drink wine, calling it by other than its name". 101 - "And Umar bin Al-Khattab may Allah be pleased with him said: Beware of the people of opinion (Ra'y), for they are enemies of Sunan, the Hadiths tired them to memorize, and escaped them to understand, and they were shy - when asked - to say: We do not know! So they opposed Sunan with their opinion, so beware of them":
I say: (The Destroyer) did not extract it, and limited himself to saying (1/490): "See 'Jami' Bayan Al-Ilm wa Fadlihi' by Ibn Abd al-Barr (2/135)"! So I say: As if his intention from this referral - from which readers benefit nothing - is only evasion from referencing it and stating its rank! The reality is that Ibn Abd al-Barr extracted it from paths from Umar; some disconnected, and some connected, but their sum indicates its establishment from Umar may Allah be pleased with him.
Oh Allah! How applicable it is to this (Destroyer)! So Glory be to Him who inspired him to write this comment; to draw the readers' attention to its applicability to him; and revealing his identity with his pen!

102 - "The Prophet peace and blessings be upon him said: 'A pregnant woman is not to be intercourse with until she delivers, nor a non-pregnant until she menstruates'".
(The Destroyer) referenced it from the Hadith of Abu Said Al-Khudri - and weakened its chain -, and from the Hadith of Abu Tha'labah, Ibn Abbas, Ruwayfi', and Al-Irbad bin Sariyah - and remained silent about them -!
Thus (the Destroyer) does; he explicitly states weakening the weak, and remains silent about the authentic! The reality is that the chains of some of them are authentic, and some Hasan, and Al-Hafiz graded the first Hasan due to others, so he blinded himself to all of that, as he blinded himself to the authentic Hadith of Jabir, and the authentic Mursal of Al-Sha'bi, and other witnesses; and they are referenced in "Al-Irwa" (1/200-201) and (5/139-142), and he definitely stood upon them, for from them he summarized - rather stole - his mentioned referencing! So he ignored them out of spite for the Sunnah and its people.
Ahmad argued with it for invalidating tricks (Hiyal) - as the author narrated from him here -, and he argued with it also in "Masa'il Ibnihi Salih" (3/196); and Imam Ahmad is sufficient proof! But (the Destroyer) has no Imam; except his desire! Ibn Abd al-Barr strengthened some of them in "Al-Tamhid" (18/279).
(Note): Among (the Destroyer's) negligences and ignorances; is that he did not distinguish the Hadith of the Prophet peace and blessings be upon him from the speech of others; for he restricted the end of the Hadith according to him with an addition in it, - thus -: "A pregnant woman is not to be intercourse with..., nor a non-pregnant until she menstruates so it is not known: Is she pregnant or not?". So he inserted - with extreme ignorance - his saying: "so it is not known" at the end of the Hadith! While it is from the completion of Imam Ahmad's speech - which Ibn al-Qayyim cited -.

I say: From this passage (The Enemy of Sunnah) only referenced the Hadith of "Al-Musnad"; thinking - and it is a mirage - that he finds in it room to weaken it, and he is a transgressing aggressor - as is his habit -, for he faulted it with two defects:
One of them: (Abdur-Rahman bin Thabit bin Thawban); so the loser asserted - from himself - that he is weak!
The other: The anonymity of (Abu Munib Al-Jurashi); he said: "No one validated him except Ibn Hibban and Al-Ijli, and they have known leniency"!
So I say seeking help from Allah:
1 - As for Ibn Thabit; the correct view regarding him is to say: "Disputed over", and Al-Hafiz explicitly stated this in "Al-Fath" (6/98); for this is the reality, for among the Imams are those who validated him, and among them are those who weakened him, and among them are those who took a middle path regarding him, and this is the justice towards which the critical Hafizs inclined who stood upon the mentioned disagreement, and applied the rules of the science of Hadith upon it; like Hafiz Al-Dhahabi; for he took a middle path regarding him: saying in "Al-Kashif": "Duhaym and others said: Trustworthy, accused of Qadar (Qadariyyah), and some softened him". And he said in "Al-Siyar" (7/313): "Duhaym and Abu Hatim validated him; and Salih - Jazarah - said: Qadari truthful". Then he mentioned the sayings of those who weakened him, then ended his biography saying: "Al-Tabarani tracked his Hadiths; they came in a full notebook, and he was not prolific,

nor is he a proof, rather Salih al-Hadith": Therefore he listed him in "Al-Ruwat Al-Mutakallam Fihim Bima La Yujibu Al-Radd" (133/200). And abbreviated his biography in "Al-Mughni" saying: "Truthful". Hafiz Al-Mundhiri preceded him to that in "Al-Targhib". Similar to it is Al-Hafiz's saying in "Al-Taqrib": "Truthful makes mistakes, and changed at the end". Therefore he affirmed his Hadith - this one - in "Al-Fath" (6/98). Indeed his Sheikh Hafiz Al-Iraqi authenticated its chain in "Takhrij Al-Ihya".
Upon that proceeded many of the early Imams, so they authenticated many Hadiths for him - like Al-Tirmidhi, Ibn Hibban, Al-Hakim, Al-Mundhiri, Al-Dhahabi - and others -, and more than one scholar used this Hadith of his as proof for the dislike of things from the attire of non-Muslims; as Sheikh Al-Islam Ibn Taymiyyah said in "Iqtida' Al-Sirat Al-Mustaqim Mukhalafat Ashab Al-Jahim", and among them Hafiz Ibn Kathir in his "Tafsir" (1/148) and his "Tarikh" (2/145), and before them Hafiz Ibn Al-Salah in "Al-Fatawa" (277/244), and he provided an important benefit; saying: "Imitating disbelievers; might be disliked, and might be forbidden, and that is according to the obscenity in it; little or much; and Allah knows best".
Among what draws attention: Is that among the validators of this (Ibn Thabit): Imam Abu Hatim Al-Razi - known for his strictness in validation -; therefore (the Destroyer) relies on him much in disparagement and declaring anonymity, but here he opposed him!
2 - As for (Abu Munib Al-Jurashi); (the Destroyer's) accusing him of anonymity - claiming leniency of his two validators -, is only from his arrogance and rejection of truth, for it is known that

it does not follow from their leniency - i.e., Ibn Hibban, and Al-Ijli - that their validation is always rejected, just as it does not follow from others being strict that their weakening is always rejected. Rather all that is subject to the science of disparagement and validation, and from it is prioritizing disparagement over validation upon contradiction - with its known condition -, and there is nothing of this here absolutely. Rather in it is the mentioned validation supported by Hafizs' authentication of this Hadith of his and others, and by the narration of five trustworthy narrators from him, and most of them are Tabi'in, so there is no one from people of knowledge who rejects the Hadith of his like due to anonymity. So there is no wonder after this that the opinion of Hafizs agrees on his validation, and the large crowd on authenticating his Hadith! All this indicates decisively that (the Destroyer) proceeds in his weakening of Hadiths from following his desire, and that he gives no weight to scholars, and Allah is the Helper!
From that, is that he did not reference what Ibn al-Qayyim pointed to of Hadiths reported regarding imitating disbelievers "...in many places" - as is the text of his speech may Allah have mercy on him, and I had collected what was facilitated for me of them at the end of my book "Hijab Al-Mar'ah Al-Muslimah" - which I named lately "Jilbab Al-Mar'ah Al-Muslimah" -, about thirty authentic Hadiths in various chapters of Sharia, in worships, transactions... and similar. From that is the Hadith: "Our guidance differs from the guidance of the disbelievers", which (the Destroyer) turned away from referencing - due to his ignorance of it! -, for I referenced it - there - from the narration of Al-Hakim - and he authenticated it -, and it has a view I explained there, but its meaning is in "Sahih Al-Bukhari", let alone other Hadiths Ibn al-Qayyim pointed to. From the perfection of his striving in destruction, is that he did not point to them, nor guide readers to them, rather - on the contrary - he ended his referencing saying - with extreme ignorance -: "And the mentioned witnesses for the Hadith are weaker"!

This is from his exaggerations and alarmism, for they contain a Mursal witness, which Al-Hafiz graded Hasan in "Al-Fath", and "Al-Taghliq" - also - (3/446). His referencing of the Hadith is among what he stole from "Al-Irwa" (1269), and took from it the faulting of its paths; except the grading Hasan of the first path, and concealed some of its manuscript sources, so his theft is not exposed; because they are not from his sources!
Among those Hadiths - which it was obligatory upon (the Destroyer) to reference - his saying peace and blessings be upon him when he saw on a man clothing of disbelievers -: "These are from the clothes of disbelievers so do not wear them"; Muslim and others narrated it, and I do not consider it unlikely for him to invent a defect for it to weaken it! And his saying peace and blessings be upon him: "Change grey hair and do not imitate Jews and Christians"; Al-Tirmidhi and Ibn Hibban authenticated it, and it has paths you see there (189-190).

104 - "He justified not combining between a woman and her paternal aunt by his saying: If you do that you sever your ties of kinship":
I say: The prohibition of the mentioned combination is authentic from the Prophet peace and blessings be upon him; from the Hadith of Abu Hurayrah in "The Two Sahihs" and others, and it is referenced in "Al-Irwa" (6/288-291).
As for the justification by his saying: "If you..." etc, it is not authentic; it is from the path of Mu'tamir bin Sulayman, from Al-Fudayl bin Maysarah, from Abu Hariz, from Ikrimah, from Ibn Abbas.
And (the Destroyer's) saying (1/552): "And perhaps it is a delusion from Al-Mu'tamir bin Sulayman": Is from his ignorance of men's standings and ranks, and his attacking without right, for (Al-Mu'tamir) is trustworthy used as proof by the Two Sheikhs and the Group; rather the delusion is from his Sheikh Al-Fudayl bin Maysarah, rather from the Sheikh of this one - Abu Hariz -, and his name is (Abdullah bin Husain); for he is weaker than him; as I verified in the fourteenth volume of "Al-Ahadith Al-Da'ifah" number (6528), and refuted those who graded this addition Hasan among contemporaries.

105 - "Return the trust to the one who entrusted you, and do not betray the one who betrayed you":
I say: Ibn al-Qayyim asserted its attribution to the Prophet peace and blessings be upon him, and it is the correct view.
As for (the Destroyer)" he said (1/505): "A weak Hadith, Abu Dawood extracted it... from the path of Talq bin Ghannam, from Sharik, and Qais bin Al-Rabi', from Abu Husayn, from Abu Salih, from Abu Hurayrah... - raised -, and Sharik and Qais are weak, and Qais is not fit for follow-up, for it used to be inserted into his book".
Thus he said: "used to be inserted" (Yudkhalu), in passive voice, he obscured the doer! To magnify the act!! And delude readers that Qais's book was available to people, anyone inserts into it whatever he wants! Of what is not from Qais's Hadith! This is false having no basis, and what scholars mentioned is that that was from the action of a son of his, when he became old. Al-Hafiz said: "Truthful, changed when he aged, and his son inserted upon him what is not of his Hadith".
I noticed that Hafiz Al-Dhahabi may Allah have mercy on him did not address mentioning this (Insertion) at all in the biography of (Qais) in all his books in which he wrote his biography - of what I stood upon -, like: "Tadhkirat Al-Huffaz", "Al-Siyar", "Al-Kashif", and "Al-Mughni", except in "Al-Mizan" in which he mentions - usually - all what was said about the biographer of disparagement and validation, yet, as if he pointed in the beginning of his biography that nothing results from it more than his saying - therein -: "Truthful in himself, bad in memory". Likewise he said in "Al-Mughni", and he summarizes in it - usually - what he mentioned in "Al-Mizan"; as if he means he was afflicted from his son's side due to his bad memory, and based on that

(the Destroyer's) saying - regarding him -: "And he is not fit for follow-up" - although he has no predecessor in it - is rejected, for it is established among scholars, that the Truthful narrator weak in his memory is used as witness, and is fit for follow-up. Perhaps because of this: He graded the chain of this Hadith - itself - good in "Talkhis Al-Ilal Al-Mutanahiyah" (581), and praise be to Allah.
Here is Abu Hatim Al-Razi - known for his strictness in disparagement - saying regarding this (Qais): "His place is truthfulness, and he is not strong, his Hadith is written, and not used as proof, and he is more beloved to me than Muhammad bin Abdur-Rahman bin Abi Layla".
I say: So he did not weaken him severely; rather indicated using him as witness by saying: "His Hadith is written"; and this is what (the Destroyer) does not understand; due to his ignorance of the intents of Imams' sayings. Ibn al-Qayyim pointed to that - as will come -; see the same Hadith number (124).
As for Ibn Adi, he graded his Hadith Hasan, saying at the end of his biography from "Al-Kamil" - after citing his son's story -: "Most of his narrations are straight, and he narrated from Shu'bah, and from Ibn Uyaynah - and others -, and that indicates that he is a man of Hadith, and the saying regarding him is what Shu'bah said, that there is no harm in him".
I say: So there is no wonder - after this - that Al-Tirmidhi grades this Hadith of his Hasan, especially since Sharik bin Abdullah the Judge was coupled with him - and Muslim used him as witness -, and that Al-Hakim, and Al-Dhahabi authenticate it, and that scholars use it as proof without known disagreement among them,

like Ibn al-Qayyim here, and his Sheikh Ibn Taymiyyah in his "Fatawa" - as will come -, and Ibn Kathir in "Al-Tafsir" (1/515) and others. This is firstly.
Secondly: His saying: "And Abu Hatim denounced it - as in 'Al-Ilal' by his son (1/375) -, and faulted it with (Talq bin Ghannam)".
I say: This is proof against (the Destroyer); because he did not fault it with (Qais) - as preceded in explanation -, and that he is fit for being used as witness according to Abu Hatim - as is apparent -. As for his faulting it with (Talq bin Ghannam); that is because he is not known to him, therefore he did not mention in his biography validation nor disparagement, so then; the defect is not damaging according to us, because a group validated him, and Al-Bukhari used him as proof in his "Sahih", moreover it is possible that his intent by denouncement is merely uniqueness (Tafarrud), not weakening, and this is a known usage among some Muhaddithin - as in "Muqaddimat Ibn Al-Salah" - and others -, and the complete phrase of Ibn Abi Hatim supports this interpretation, perhaps - therefore - (the Destroyer) truncated it and did not mention it completely; misleading - as is his habit -!
Ibn Abi Hatim said, from his father regarding (Talq): "And he narrated a denounced Hadith from Sharik and Qais"; so he cited it, and said: "My father said: And no one narrated this Hadith other than him". This is very explicit that he meant uniqueness, and Al-Bukhari pointed to this - also - by mentioning this Hadith in the biography of (Talq) from "Al-Tarikh" (2/2/360); so Abu Hatim's phrase returned as destruction on (the Destroyer's) head; and praise be to Allah always.
Third - and lastly -: His saying: "And its witnesses all are not authentic, and this is the best of them; and see

So I say: This is a fallacy of his many fallacies, or a weak expression, for it is known - intuitively - that authenticity is not conditioned in witnesses, but rather safety from severe weakness, and this is realized here, for the witnesses mentioned in "Al-Talkhis" are four:
First: Contains Ayyub bin Suwayd, Al-Hafiz said: "Disputed over".
Second: Contains an unknown person, and Ibn Al-Sakan authenticated it.
Third: Its chain is weak.
Fourth: From Al-Hasan - Mursal.
I say: I had referenced these witnesses - except the fourth - in "Al-Sahihah" (423), and ended them refuting Ibn al-Jawzi - whom (the Destroyer) imitated - by saying: "I say: This is of his exaggerations, for the Hadith from the first path is Hasan, and these witnesses and paths raise it to the degree of Authenticity, due to the difference of their exits, and their freedom from an accused person".
So it was obligatory upon (the Destroyer) to answer this Refutation with a scientific answer, but he - as is his habit - evaded to misleading referral! Acting on the colloquial proverb: (A goat even if it flew)!
Moreover, there are other follow-ups, increasing the Hadith strength upon strength, therefore he concealed them. From that; Ayyub bin Suwayd has a strong follower in "Mu'jam Al-Tabarani" (1/234/760) with a good chain, and Al-Haythami documented its men in "Al-Majma'" (4/145), and Al-Diya' Al-Maqdisi extracted it - also - in "Al-Mukhtarah".

And Al-Hasan Al-Basri's Mursal was suspended by Al-Bayhaqi, and Al-Tabari connected it in his "Tafsir" (5/93) with an authentic chain from him. And it has a witness - in meaning -; Ibn al-Qayyim mentioned it in "Al-Ighatha" (2/89); and (the Destroyer) authenticated it!
As for what Ibn al-Jawzi quoted from Imam Ahmad that he said: "This is a false Hadith, I do not know it from a valid path": I do not think it is authentic from the Imam, nor did he attribute it to a book that can be referred to (1); and if authentic: The answer is what preceded.
The first half of the Hadith is in the text of the Holy Quran: {Indeed, Allah commands you to render trusts to whom they are due}.
And for the other half of it there is a witness with its meaning, Ibn Taymiyyah may Allah have mercy on him mentioned it in "Al-Fatawa" (30/371-375) in a speech of his regarding this Hadith, containing very important benefits from the Fiqh perspective; which (the Destroyer) does not care about at all! So he said may Allah have mercy on him following it -: "And in 'Al-Musnad' from Bashir Ibn Al-Khasasiyah, that he said: O Messenger of Allah! Indeed we have neighbors who do not leave for us a stray or odd thing except they take it, so if we have power over something of theirs shall we take it? He said: 'No! Return the trust to the one who entrusted you, and do not betray the one who betrayed you', and in 'Al-Sunan' from the Prophet peace and blessings be upon him, that it was said to him: Indeed the people of Sadaqah transgress against us, shall we hide from our wealth the amount they transgress against us? He said: 'No', Abu Dawood narrated it".

I say: Bashir's Hadith in "Al-Musnad" (5/83) - is similar to it -, but it does not contain: "Return the trust...", and likewise it is in "Atraf Al-Musnad" by Hafiz Ibn Hajar (1/635/1288); so the apparent is that it is inserted by some copyists, or it is an illusion from the Sheikh may Allah have mercy on him, and this is the apparent; for the author mentioned it - coming under number (126) - attributing it to his Sheikh in the book "Ibtal Al-Tahlil" and it is in (p. 94) of it, and this illusion passed on (the Destroyer) - as will be mentioned - there -.
And what he attributed to Abu Dawood: is in his "Sunan" (1586) from the Hadith of Bashir - also -, and with the same chain. And Abdur-Razzaq cited the two Hadiths in his "Musannaf" with the same chain, and in it is a Sheikh from Banu Sadus - called: Daysam -, and he is unknown, therefore I referenced his Hadith in "Da'if Sunan Abi Dawood" (277); but he is a covered Tabi'i, so there is no harm in him in witnesses, and Allah Almighty knows best.

106 - Ibn al-Qayyim may Allah have mercy on him said: "And the Sunnah proceeded on the dislike of singling out Rajab with fasting, and singling out Friday".
I say: (The Destroyer) referenced its first half with the Hadith of Ibn Abbas, that the Prophet peace and blessings be upon him forbade fasting Rajab, he said: "And in it is a discarded (Matruk) narrator". He only said that to escape referencing it, because the Hadith has no basis with this completeness in a book of Sunnah books I stood upon, rather it is composed of two Hadiths; one of them: This Hadith of Bashir, and it is in "Al-Musnad" and others, and the other the Hadith of Abu Hurayrah: "Return the trust...", so the matter became confused for some so they made them one Hadith, as I verified at the end of the previous Hadith (105), and the matter passed on (the Destroyer) so he did not know what to do?! So he said what he said! Likewise he did not notice the dropping of the particle (No) at the end of Bashir's Hadith, and this is his verification!

128 - "Ahmad argued with what he narrated from Abu Umamah bin Sahl, from Sa'id bin Sa'd bin Ubadah, he said: There was among our houses a weak emaciated little man, so the neighborhood was not startled except he was upon a maid of their maids; acting foully with her... so he peace and blessings be upon him said: 'Take for him a raceme (Ithkal) containing a hundred stalks, then strike him with it one blow', so they did":

text:
I say: In Ahmad's chain is the 'an'anah of Muhammad bin Ishaq, and he is a Mudallis, yet Al-Hafiz graded its chain Hasan in "Bulugh Al-Maram", and it is authentic due to others as will be explained.
As for (the Destroyer) he referenced it in four lines; three of them mentioning its extractors! And commented on them saying: "...with different chains and paths, from Abu Umamah bin Sahl, he sends it Mursal and connects it to more than one, and authenticity predominates it, see 'Al-Talkhis Al-Habir' (4/59)".
Thus he said! And in it are important objections:
Among them: That he did not explain the face of authenticity in this odd phrase of his, which the most ignorant of people is not incapable of! (Habit...).
And among them: That he referred in it to "Al-Talkhis"; deluding readers that Al-Hafiz preferred the connected one in it, and the reality is contrary to it; as I explained in detail at the end of the sixth volume of "Al-Sahihah" (2986), in about seven pages, I collected in it of paths what you do not see collected - with weighing preference between them - in another place, I reached from it to verify that the Hadith - even if authentic as Mursal from Abu Umamah bin Sahl, and Al-Daraqutni, Al-Bayhaqi and Al-Hafiz preferred it -, it is authentic connected (Musnad) from the narration of two trustworthy narrators from Abu Hatim, from Sahl bin Sa'd... raised, Al-Hafiz did not stand upon the narration of the more trustworthy of them, and it is in "Sunan Al-Nasa'i Al-Kubra", and witnessed for by one of the narrations from Abu Umamah; that some Companions of the Messenger of Allah peace and blessings be upon him from the Ansar informed him - and he is this Sahl bin Sa'd -, and Allah knows best.
And see the rest of objections on (the Destroyer) in the place referred to from "Al-Sahihah".

I say: (The Destroyer) referenced it from the narration of a group - among them Al-Tirmidhi and Al-Baghawi -, from paths from Khalid bin Abdullah, from Humayd Al-Tawil, from Anas; and said: "And they are trustworthy".

I say: (The Destroyer) asserted its weakness, and referenced it with a weak chain from Al-Hasan Mursal, and from Aisha with a chain containing one accused of lying.
I say: Such is not used as witness, but (the Destroyer) concealed another path - from Aisha - safe from this accused one, and it is valid for witnessing, Al-Bayhaqi extracted it in "Al-Ba'th" (1); just as he concealed another witness from the Hadith of Anas; mentioned by Al-Iraqi in "Takhrij Al-Ihya", and weakened it, just as witnessing for it - in general - is his saying peace and blessings be upon him: "The people of Paradise enter Paradise hairless, beardless, kohl-eyed, aged thirty-three", Al-Tirmidhi graded it Hasan, and it is authentic by the sum of its paths - as explained in some of my comments -, and you find detailed speech on the Hadith of the title in "Al-Sahihah" (2987).

(The Destroyer) weakened it according to what he proceeded on of not strengthening Hadith by the sum of its paths; contrary to what scholars are upon in knowledge and practice, therefore Al-Hafiz indicated in "Al-Fath" (1/47) strengthening it, and likewise Al-Mundhiri in "Targhibuhu" (4/49).

text: And (Al-Haddam) [The Destroyer], when he extracted it and discussed its paths, only (took) that from my book "Al-Sahihah"! He brought no addition worth mentioning other than opposition. Rather, he was finally compelled to prove that he is dependent on it, saying: (2/150): "And he mentioned in 'Al-Sahihah' (998) another chain in Al-Tabarani from Ibn Mas'ud, and it is weak"! I say: The facet of opposition is: giving the illusion to the readers that I am the one saying: "And it is weak"! And this is a lie; for I said following its attribution to Al-Tabarani: "I say: This is a Hasan (good) chain in corroborating reports (Shawahid) and follow-ups (Mutaba'at), and its men are trustworthy, and there is speech regarding some of them; but it does not harm in this [context]." 132 - "Whoever loves for Allah, hates for Allah, gives for Allah, and withholds for Allah; has completed faith": (Al-Haddam) weakened it as well (2/150), and prolonged the discussion - in vain - in its extraction and speaking about some of its narrators! Mixing between one who is Hasan al-Hadith (good in hadith) and one who is suitable for citation as a witness!! While selecting the sayings of the strict ones in criticism (Jarh); which would take very long to explain and refute. I had authenticated the hadith based on the sum of two Hasan paths; I extracted them in "Al-Sahihah" (385): One of them: From the path of Yahya bin Al-Harith, from Al-Qasim bin Abd al-Rahman, from Abu Umamah. And the other: From the path of Abd al-Rahim bin Maymun, from Sahl bin Mu'adh bin Anas Al-Juhani, from his father. So what did (Al-Haddam) do to weaken them?! He said regarding each of (Al-Qasim) in

We have mentioned repeatedly that every hadith with a Hasan chain was not Hasan except because there is weakness in it, otherwise it would be Sahih (authentic). This is the nature of the hadiths that (Al-Haddam) grades as Hasan - despite their scarcity -. Therefore; his saying regarding each one of these narrators: "There is weakness in him"; only indicates that he is Hasan al-Hadith! If only he knew what he was saying!! Then he does not know the difference between the narration of Abd al-Rahim from Sahl, and the narration of Zabban from him. Al-Hafiz said in "Al-Taqrib" in the biography of (Sahl bin Mu'adh): "There is no harm in him, except in the narration of Zabban from him." And (Al-Haddam) confused the two narrations from Sahl, and did not distinguish between them; due to his ignorance of the conditions of the narrators, and the exclusivity of one of them with the Sheikh over the others! Then (Al-Haddam) did not suffice with his previous saying regarding (Al-Qasim bin Abd al-Rahman), but added, saying: "And some of them do not affirm hearing for him from Abu Umamah"! I say: This (Some) has no existence except in the mind of (Al-Haddam), and perhaps he means himself, and that is not far-fetched for an arrogant ignoramus accustomed to arrogance and denying facts; for the Imams have agreed on affirming his hearing from him, including Al-Bukhari in "Al-Tarikh". Rather, Al-Dhahabi said in "Al-Kashif" - after mentioning his narration from Mu'awiyah and Amr bin Abasa -: "And it was said: He did not hear from a Companion other than Abu Umamah." Everyone who wrote his biography asserted his hearing from him; such as Al-Mizzi and Al-Asqalani - and others -; and he has in "Al-Musnad" (5/264), "Al-Ruyani" (Folio 200/2), and "Kabir al-Tabarani"

Therefore, Al-Hafiz - also - indicated the strengthening of the hadith in the place previously referred to, and likewise Al-Mundhiri. 133 - "The statement of the Prophet (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him): 'Charity is not permissible for a rich person, nor for one of strength and sound body'": I say: He extracted it through the narration of a group from the hadith of Abu Hurayrah, and said: "It is an authentic hadith due to its witnessing reports, see 'Al-Ihsan' (3290)." I say: He combined - with this reference to 'Al-Ihsan' - between falsehood and injustice! As for falsehood, he gave the illusion to the readers that his mentioned authentication is in 'Al-Ihsan'; while the reality is contrary to it. For he [Ibn Hibban/The editor of Ihsan] strengthened the chain of Abu Hurayrah via the group by itself, and authenticated another chain from him, and also strengthened the chain of its witness from the hadith of Ibn Amr! And in all of that, there is a view [reservation] in my opinion, which I clarified in 'Al-Irwa' (3/381-385), and I extracted them - more simply than in 'Al-Ihsan' - along with two other witnesses that were not extracted in it, one of them from a man from Banu Bilal who heard it from the Prophet (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him), and its chain is good (Jayyid). As for the injustice, it is that he only derived the authenticity he mentioned from the sum of these four hadiths, so justice and fairness required him to refer to 'Al-Irwa', so as not to fall into violation of His saying - the Exalted -: {And do not deprive people of their due things}. 134 - Ibn al-Qayyim (may Allah have mercy on him) mentioned the Angels, saying: "The heaven has creaked [groaned] because of them, and it has the right to creak; there is no place of four fingers in it except there is an angel standing, bowing, or prostrating." And "Seventy thousand angels enter the Frequented House [Al-Bayt Al-Ma'mur] every day, never returning to it, [this is] the last of their duty toward it."

book_title: The Advice Warning against the Destruction by (Ibn Abd al-Mannan) of the Preponderant Books of Imams and His Weakening of Hundreds of Authentic Hadiths

text: (Al-Haddam) said (2/157), placing the commentary number at the end of the Hadith of the Frequented House: "A weak hadith, we referred to it in 'Riyad al-Salihin', published by the Islamic Office"! I say: The owner of the Islamic Office - may Allah reform me and him - fell into trouble, so he printed the book "Al-Riyad" for him [Al-Haddam], which is known for the alteration and changing of its original text! And the weakening of dozens of authentic hadiths! My assumption is that this was before his ignorance of this noble science became clear to him, and his setting himself up to oppose the scholars of Hadith and their Imams, and contradicting them in their rulings; so he is in one rank, and they are in another!! In what preceded - and what is to come - is the greatest proof of that, such that it leaves no doubt or suspicion in the heart of anyone who (might) still think well of him - due to his pedantry - that he is deviant from the path of the scholars. And here he is now presenting a new example of what we mentioned; and here is the explanation: First, he imagined - due to his ignorance of the Sunnah - that the Hadith of Creaking (Atit) and the Hadith of the Frequented House are one hadith; therefore he placed the commentary number at the end of the Hadith of the House, and weakened it, while the Hadith of the House is authentic and agreed upon between the Two Sheikhs [Bukhari and Muslim] - as will come -. He has much of such confusion, and perhaps some of it preceded - or will come -. Why do we go far?! Here is the example in what he referred to from "his Riyad", and he refers to the hadith he included in "his appendix" (p. 512): "14 - Hadith of Abu Dharr: I see what you do not see, and I hear what you do not hear, the heaven creaked..." so he mentioned it in its entirety - as it is in "Al-Sahihah" (1722) -. It contains four paragraphs, which I see as [part of] advice to detail, and to clarify (Al-Haddam's) stance towards them, and the extent of his crime against most of them; for the sake of one of them! The First: The Hadith of Creaking - which is here.

book_title: The Advice Warning against the Destruction by (Ibn Abd al-Mannan) of the Preponderant Books of Imams and His Weakening of Hundreds of Authentic Hadiths

text: The Second: "By Allah, if you knew what I know, you would laugh little and weep much." The Third: "And you would not enjoy women on beds." The Fourth: "And you would go out to the roads beseeching Allah - the Exalted." I say: (Al-Haddam) said - there - after extracting it: "It contains Ibrahim bin Muhajir, and he is weak, and parts of it have witnesses, but it is not authentic in its entirety (length)"! I say: You see that he obscured the matter for the readers! He restricted the weakening to its length, and its implication is that part of it is authentic, and he supported it by saying: "and parts of it have witnesses", but he concealed them and did not clarify what they are!! Thereby the reader remains confused; because (Al-Haddam) intended that by not distinguishing what is authentic from it from what is not! As if the saying of the Prophet (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him): "Religion is advice..." is not valid to him, otherwise he would not have concealed the truth, and would have hastened to clarify it, especially since most of the hadith is authentic - if I don't say: all of it - as will come. In that case, what is the benefit of the mentioned weakening except destruction?! As for the first sentence: It is authentic with its witnesses, among which is the hadith of Hakim bin Hizam with an authentic chain, as I clarified in "Al-Sahihah" (852 and 1060). And from the completeness of (Al-Haddam's) breach of scientific honesty; is that he referred in the end of his extraction - the referred one - to this witness, but he remained as silent as a deaf stone, neither indicating its authenticity! Nor its weakness! And he who lacks a thing cannot give it!! As for the second sentence; it is in the "Two Sahihs" from the hadith of Anas, and in "Al-Bukhari" - also - from the hadith of Abu Hurayrah, and they are extracted in "Al-Sahihah" (3194), and "Fiqh al-Seerah" (479). So contemplate the extent of this (Haddam's) crime against the authentic Sunnah, by not excepting this sentence at least from the weakness he mentioned, and Allah is the One sought for help!

text: As for the third: I have not yet found what strengthens it. And the fourth sentence: It has some witnesses, and therefore I included it with the first sentence in "Sahih al-Jami' al-Saghir" grading it Hasan, and referring to Al-Da'ifah (4354). (Note): I had included the hadith of Abu Dharr in "Al-Sahihah" under number (1722), and I missed - at that time - mentioning the witnesses strengthening it, and I do not know - by Allah - how that happened?! For it is contrary to my inclination and methodology. Just as I had included it in "Al-Da'ifah" - also - (1780); and the reason is clear, which is to clarify the interpolation of the sentence that came at its end with the wording: "And I wish I were a tree to be cut down", and that it is Mawquf (stopped) on Abu Dharr; therefore I hastened to say at the end of the extraction in accordance with the methodology: "But most of the hadith has been authenticated from other paths..." And this - or similar to it - should have been in "Al-Sahihah" - also -, rather it is more deserving of it, but thus Allah decreed; so Exalted is He who does not overlook nor forget, and apologies to the readers, and let the referred witnesses be transferred there. 135 - "In 'Sahih Ibn Hibban' - from him (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him): 'The best Dhikr (remembrance) is La ilaha illa Allah'." (Al-Haddam) extracted it from a group - among them Al-Tirmidhi, Ibn Hibban, Al-Hakim, and Al-Baghawi - from paths, from Musa bin Ibrahim bin Kathir Al-Ansari, from Talha bin Khirash, from Jabir; and he weakened it saying: "And this Musa, no one declared him trustworthy other than Ibn Hibban, and he added: And he used to err, and what appears is that [in] his narration from Talha there are denounced reports (Manakir), and Al-Azdi indicated that the denouncement is in the hadith of Talha, from Jabir."

book_title: The Advice Warning against the Destruction by (Ibn Abd al-Mannan) of the Preponderant Books of Imams and His Weakening of Hundreds of Authentic Hadiths

text: I say: He has objections against him, some more denounced than others: First: His saying: "...other than Ibn Hibban" is an intentional lie! For he saw in "Tahdhib Al-Mizzi": "Ibn Abd al-Barr said Musa and Talha; both are Medinan and trustworthy." So he intentionally ignored Ibn Abd al-Barr's authentication of him; evidenced by the fact that the three hadiths he will mention for Musa - as will come -; he only found them in "Al-Tahdhib"! Rather, in "Tahdhib Ibn Hajar" from Al-Nasa'i - regarding him - is his saying: "Salih" (Righteous/Good). Second: He ignored - also - the authentication of Ibn Hibban, Al-Hakim, and Al-Dhahabi, just as he ignored the grading of Hasan by Al-Tirmidhi and Al-Baghawi, so he did not mention it from them - as is his habit -! Third: He relied on Ibn Hibban's saying regarding (Musa): "And he used to err"; giving the illusion that this is a weakening from Ibn Hibban for Musa, and it is not so, as is known to those who study this saying of Ibn Hibban. For he only implies that he is average, Hasan al-Hadith (good in hadith). There are hundreds of biographies in his book where he said this - or similar -, yet he extracts from them in his "Sahih", and this is one of them. Was (Al-Haddam) ignorant of this or did he ignore it?! The sweeter of the two is bitter!! Similar to it is Al-Hafiz's saying in "Al-Taqrib" - regarding him -: "Saduq (Truthful) who errs." Yet he confirmed in "Al-Fath" (11/207) the authentication of Ibn Hibban and Al-Hakim for him. Fourth: He did not enclose the mentioned saying of Ibn Hibban between double quotation marks as is the terminology today: " "; rather he followed it with his saying: "and what appears...", giving the understanding - and illusion - that it is from the completion of Ibn Hibban's speech! And it is not so!! Fifth: It could be from his ignorance and poor expression, and that the mentioned deduction is from himself! In that case, we say to him: (This is not your nest, so go away)! What is the value of

Sixth: His saying: "And Al-Azdi indicated that the denouncement is in the hadith of Talha, from Jabir": is from his poor expression - as well -. For Al-Azdi explicitly stated that, saying: "Talha narrated denounced reports from Jabir"; but Al-Azdi is criticized (Majruh); so no attention is paid to his criticism, especially if he opposes! Then (Al-Haddam) said: "And Musa has three hadiths... appearing to be Munkar", then he mentioned them! Thus he said! And you must submit in submission to the Muhaddith of the End Times!! As for the first hadith, it is this one, and you have known his aggression by weakening it, and his opposition to the scholars. The second hadith: "The Fire will not touch a Muslim who saw me, or saw one who saw me." And the third: "Allah never spoke to anyone except from behind a veil, and He spoke to your father directly (kifahan)." I say: And all three are in Al-Tirmidhi, and he said regarding each one of them: "A Hasan Gharib (strange) hadith," and a number of scholars confirmed him on that; Al-Mizzi in "Al-Tahdhib" (13/393-395); and mention has preceded of those who authenticated and graded it Hasan before him. As for the second hadith: Along with Al-Tirmidhi and Al-Mizzi grading it Hasan - as I mentioned just now - it has a witness from the hadith of Uqbah Abu Abd al-Rahman Al-Juhani - in Ibn Abi Asim in "Al-Sunnah" (2/630/1485), and Al-Tabarani in "Al-Kabir" (17/357/983), and "Al-Awsat" (1/57/1011) via the path of Abd al-Rahman bin Uqbah, from his father... raised - similar to it -. But this Abd al-Rahman, I did not find a biography for him, nor for the narrator from him Nafi' bin Sayfi, and Al-Haythami pointed to them saying (10/21) after attributing it

As for the third hadith: Al-Hakim extracted it (3/204) - and authenticated it also -, and Al-Mundhiri improved its chain in "Al-Targhib" (2/191), and it has a Mursal witness in "Al-Jihad" by Ibn Abi Asim (Folio 2/90), and a witness from the hadith of Jabir briefly, extracted by Ahmad (3/361) with a Hasan Sahih chain, and it is extracted in "Al-Sahihah" number (3290), and Al-Hafiz remained silent about it in "Al-Isabah" (2/350), and Ibn Abd al-Barr indicated in the biography of (Abdullah) father of (Jabir) - from "Al-Isti'ab" - its strengthening by explicitly stating the trustworthiness of (Talha bin Khirash), and the narrator from him (Musa bin Ibrahim). 136 - "The supplication of Dhul-Nun; which, no distressed person supplicated with it except Allah relieved his distress: There is no deity except You; exalted are You. Indeed, I have been of the wrongdoers": The author asserted it, so he was correct. And (Al-Haddam) opposed him - as is his habit -, so he weakened it! He extracted it (2/162) from the narration of Al-Tirmidhi, Al-Nasa'i, Ahmad, and Al-Hakim; he said: "From paths, from Yunus bin Abi Ishaq, from Ibrahim bin Muhammad bin Sa'd, from his father, from Sa'd... raised, and its chain is capable of being Hasan; were it not for what Al-Tirmidhi mentioned following it: 'And more than one person narrated this hadith from Yunus... and did not mention in it: from his father'...; and upon this the hadith would be disconnected..."! I say: Al-Tirmidhi means by his saying: "from his father" (Muhammad bin Sa'd) the father of (Ibrahim), and in the speech of (Al-Haddam) there are ignorances:

book_title: The Advice Warning against the Destruction by (Ibn Abd al-Mannan) of the Preponderant Books of Imams and His Weakening of Hundreds of Authentic Hadiths

text: First: His saying "from paths"; he did not specify them, nor did he mention their number! To mislead the readers - as will be explained -. Second: His saying: "capable of being Hasan"; this is from his bias and crime against trustworthy narrators, paving the way to weaken the hadith; for the men of the mentioned chain are all trustworthy, therefore Al-Hakim authenticated it, and Al-Dhahabi agreed with him, and (Al-Haddam) concealed that - as is his habit -. There is no one among them spoken of except Yunus bin Abi Ishaq, and there is slight speech regarding him that does not harm, for Muslim used him as proof, and Ibn Hibban authenticated more than one hadith for him, and Al-Dhahabi mentioned him in "Those who were spoken of but are trustworthy", and said in "Al-Mizan": "Truthful, there is no harm in him, he is not in the strength of Mis'ar nor Shu'ba." Someone like him is Hasan al-Hadith - at least -, which Al-Hafiz explicitly stated - as will come -, therefore he remained silent about the hadith in "Al-Fath", and confirmed Al-Hakim's authentication of it (11/147). Third: (Al-Haddam) was not satisfied even with the capability he claimed, for he rejected it by saying: "Were it not for what Al-Tirmidhi mentioned following it..." etc., so he weakened it due to interruption, imitating Al-Tirmidhi in his saying: That more than one person narrated the hadith from Yunus disconnectedly, without mentioning: "from his father"! So he sufficed with imitation here; because it agreed with a desire in himself, which is weakening the hadith without right, otherwise why did he not look into whom Al-Tirmidhi referred to by saying: "more than one person"; who are they?! What is their number?! What is their status?! And are they valid - or is he valid - to oppose the paths that connected the hadith, which he pointed to - as preceded -?! And he did not specify them to strike them with this saying of Al-Tirmidhi!! Al-Tirmidhi mentioned that Muhammad bin Yusuf and Abu Ahmad Al-Zubayri connected it (1), then
foot_note: 1. (1) I say: The narration of Muhammad bin Yusuf is the narration of Al-Tirmidhi and others, and the narration of Al-Zubayri is in Al-Bazzar (3150).

text: he allowed himself to prefer over them the narration of "more than one person"! - while he does not know them! - over their narration, so how is it permissible for Al-Haddam to imitate him in that while he does not know them?! Conversely, he knows the two whom Al-Tirmidhi named, and he knows a third trustworthy narrator who shared with them in the narration of connection, who is (Ismail bin Umar), in the narration of Ahmad, and (Muhammad bin Ubayd Al-Tanafisi) the trustworthy Hafiz followed them in Al-Bayhaqi in "Al-Shu'ab" (1/432). These are four trustworthy narrators who connected it by mentioning in their chain - from Yunus -: "from his father", so how was it permissible for Al-Haddam to ignore these and prefer the narration of those who contradicted them while he does not know them?! By Allah, it is one of the great [calamities]!
